abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the project as
            marginally satisfactory, similarly, the institutional
            development impact is rated modest, and, as for
            sustainability, the rating is considered uncertain, given
            the negligible project design, and implementation which did
            not address the issue of sustainability. It is considered
            that the project succeeded in demonstrating the technical
            feasibility of reducing emissions of greenhouse gases, and
            simultaneously reducing local contamination, through
            widespread installation of high efficiency lighting,
            however, the project failed to demonstrate the financial
            feasibility of such endeavor, contributing only modestly,
            towards building the institutional capacity for
            technological change, energy conservation, and demand-side
            management at the implementing utility. Among the many
            lessons, it is suggested that: 1) replicability, and
            sustainability are essential elements in demonstration
            projects, and deserve close consideration, and, be
            explicitly incorporated in the project design, strategy, and
            activities; 2) the well planned implementation scheme -
            based on decentralized units, and independent trust funds -
            was successful, giving the implementing agency an overall
            project control; and, 3) bulk procurement can be an
            important leverage.
